newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Strike at Engen refinery continues.
newsitem.headline: Strike at Engen refinery continues.

text.p: A strike by 120 of the 520 workers at Engen's Durban refinery had not affected production because the refinery was already down for maintenance, general manager Peter Dent said on Thursday.

The workers, who began their strike on Monday afternoon, are demanding that written warnings issued last Tuesday for a two hour work stoppage in support of the Chemical Workers Industrial Union (CWIU) be withdrawn, Dent told Reuters.

"The strike has not affected production at all because we were down for maintenance any way. The supply situation is unaffected because we have plenty in tankage and also recently received imports," Dent said.
The strike was restricted to workers from the operating areas of the plant, he said.
Dent said management and union representatives were locked in negotiations but declined to say how they were going or when agreement could be reached.
"We are talking and that is a positive sign. (Engen) is trying desperately to get the guys to go back to work," he said.

Dent did not specify what disciplinary action would be taken against the striking workers when they resumed work, but warned: "You can't just walk off a live, operating plant and expect nothing to happen."
Union officials were unavailable for comment.
